intro: Sida transvaalensis, commonly known as Transvaal mallow, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to southern Africa. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its palmate leaves and showy, five-petaled flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its flowers, which range in color from white to pink, bloom throughout the growing season, making it an attractive addition to gardens. Sida transvaalensis is also known for its fibrous stems, which have been used in traditional crafts and basketry.
